1. A 3-year-old boy was brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents due to a progressively enlarging neck mass and intermittent difficulty breathing over the past month. They also noted episodes of night sweats and unintentional weight loss. On examination, the child had mild facial swelling and distended neck veins, suggesting possible superior vena cava syndrome. Chest X-ray revealed a widened mediastinum, and subsequent MRI showed a well-defined mass in the anterior mediastinum. Laboratory tests demonstrated elevated urine vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and homovanillic acid (HVA) levels. The child’s initial full blood count was unremarkable, and there were no signs of infection. A biopsy of the mass confirmed the diagnosis of mediastinal neuroblastoma. The patient was referred to oncology for staging and initiation of chemotherapy.
